awd_titl_txt: Statistical Modelling and Inference for Next-Generation Functional Data
awd_abstract_narration:
With the rapid growth of modern technology, many large-scale imaging studies have been or are being conducted to collect massive datasets with large volumes of imaging data, thus boosting the investigation of "next-generation functional data". These enormous collections of imaging data contain interesting information and valuable knowledge, which has raised the demand for further advancement in functional data analytic approaches. Although functional data analysis (FDA) has gained widespread popularity in recent years, enhancing the capability of next-generation FDA remains a long-standing challenge. This research targets integrating state-of-the-art statistical modeling devices with modern computational and inferential techniques to develop a set of flexible and intelligent statistical tools to enable learning and discovery from next-generation functional data. The efficacy of the tools developed in this research will be tested by neuroimaging studies. The proposed methods and theory are also applicable to a broader range of fields that require modeling and analysis of images and other complex data types collected over space and/or time, such as geography, environmental science and remote sensing studies. The graduate student support will be used for day-to-day research activities, including parts of the theory/methodology developments and data analysis. 

This research will enrich the methods for dealing with functional data observed from complex data objects (high-dimensional, correlated images or shapes), which commonly arise in imaging studies, such as, health/medical imaging or remote sensing imaging. The PI aims to address some challenging research problems in analyzing next-generation functional data by: (1) innovating a statistically sound framework to extract useful information from large-scale longitudinal imaging studies; (2) developing flexible and intelligent statistical models to delineate the association between massive imaging data and covariates of interest and to characterize and visualize the spatial variability of the imaging data; and (3) developing efficient, scalable algorithms with high-performance statistical software packages to meet the challenges posed by dynamic imaging studies. In particular, the proposed research involves four projects. Project 1 provides a unifying approach to characterize the varying association between imaging responses with a set of explanatory variables. Project 2 focuses on the interface between high-dimensional and next-generation functional data to address several fundamental bottlenecks in large-scale imaging genetics studies. Projects 3 and 4 deal with longitudinal/dynamic imaging studies, and a comprehensive functional regression framework to analyze repeated functional responses from these studies will be developed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Amid the rapid surge of technological progress, the landscape of large-scale imaging studies (e.g., biomedical imaging studies and remote sensing imaging studies) has dramatically expanded, ushering in a wealth of voluminous "next-generation functional data." To navigate this new landscape, the PI and her team embarked on a visionary endeavor, integrating cutting-edge statistical models in the realm of functional data analysis with contemporary computational techniques and robust statistical theories. In this project, the team aimed to forge a comprehensive suite of adaptable, intelligent statistical models tailor-made for the demands of next-generation functional data such as imaging data, spatiotemporal data, and data collected from complex 3D objects. All are underpinned by formal statistical inference tools.

The efforts of the research have yielded substantial and profound outcomes. By deftly addressing challenges such as the complexity of objects, various types of noises, extremely high dimensionality, heterogeneity within subjects and across groups, and complex spatiotemporal structures, the proposed methods have significantly expanded the realm of smoothing and estimation techniques to denoise the images while preserving inherent geometric features or spatial structures.

These outcomes were validated through rigorous testing with neuroimaging and spatiotemporal data. The statistical methodologies developed empower the analysis of next-generation functional data. They not only quantify and visually present estimator variability but also furnish inference tools crucial for large and complex data across time and space.

In addition, the PI and her research team have engineered computationally efficient and scalable algorithms, culminating in the creation of high-performance statistical software packages. This achievement has bolstered the availability of data analysis tools and software for next-generation functional data, encompassing dynamic/longitudinal imaging data, spatiotemporal data, high-dimensional data, and data distributed over intricate domains.

The findings from this project signify a substantial leap forward in statistical analysis theory and methodology. Culminating in practical, impactful tools, they stand poised to address the multifaceted challenges inherent to modern data landscapes.

The project offers graduate students comprehensive training and a profound understanding of the essential statistical tools required to dissect functional data endowed with intricate features. As part of this effort, the PI has guided and continues to guide eight Ph.D. students at both Iowa State University and George Mason University, aligning their dissertation projects with the overarching goals of this initiative. Notably, four Ph.D. candidates have already completed their studies under the PI's supervision, and three of these students have ascended to academia as tenure-track Assistant Professors.

Throughout the duration of the NSF grant, the research team has achieved a significant milestone with 27 papers successfully published in both peer-reviewed statistical and interdisciplinary journals, while an additional five papers are either submitted or currently in development. Several high-impact contributions have graced prestigious journals, including the Journal of the American Statistical Association and Biometrics. As part of their efforts, user-friendly R packages have been developed by the PI and her students, streamlining the practical implementation of the formulated methodologies. To communicate the project's results, the findings have been presented through over 30 invited talks at various seminars, colloquia, and prestigious national and international conferences.

In response to COVID-19 challenges, the research team has extensively committed to COVID-19 modeling and related studies. This commitment is underscored by a substantial track record of publications and contributions to this critical field, including a comprehensive book that introduces advanced data science for the analysis of infectious disease data and two R packages. One prominent outcome of our work is the development of an extensive dashboard enriched with multiple R Shiny apps. This dashboard empowers users with short-term and long-term forecasts of infection and mortality rates at the county level across the US. The PI and her research team have also participated in studies investigating the distinctive features of the US housing system, particularly landlord decision-making during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The proposed research has facilitated interdisciplinary collaboration between statisticians and researchers from biomedical research, neuroimaging, earth science, atmospheric science, and housing market studies.

 


Last Modified: 08/20/2023
Modified by: Lily Wang
